brace.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to mentally or physically prepare yourself or someone else for something unpleasant that is going to happen
brace.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Nancy braced herself for the inevitable arguments.
The military needs to brace itself for further spending cuts, says McCoy.
Cathy braced herself to see Matthew, who she expected to arrive at any minute.
The base was braced for an attack.
brace.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to push part of your body against something solid in order to make yourself more steady
brace.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Gina braced her back against the wall and pushed as hard as she could.
The pilot told passengers and crew to brace themselves for a rough landing.
brace.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to make something stronger by supporting it
brace.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Wait until weâ€™ve braced the ladder.
Workers used steel beams to brace the roof.
brace.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to make your body or part of your body stiff in order to prepare to do something difficult
brace.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: something that is used to strengthen or support something, or to make it stiff
brace.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: The miners used special braces to keep the walls from collapsing.
She had to wear a brace after the accident.
He was being fitted for a back brace.
brace.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: a system of metal wires that people, usually children, wear on their teeth to make them grow straight
brace.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: a metal support that someone with weak legs wears to help them walk
brace.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: one of a pair of signs { } used to show that information written between them should be considered together
